Extinction through discernment has been discussed.
Obstruction of future arising is attained through non-discernment.

This dharma really exists, as will be established later. It accords with the order of the main text.
Previously it was said that excluding the path, the remaining conditioned dharmas are called contaminated.
What are the conditioned?
They should be explained.
The verse says:
Also, all conditioned dharmas, namely the five aggregates such as form,
Are also called the path of the world, and are said to have separation, have things, etc.
The treatise says:
Because old age, sickness, death, and other calamities and differences are hidden and accumulated, they are called aggregates.
In order to distinguish them from precepts and so forth, it is said form, etc.
The five aggregates such as precepts cannot fully include all conditioned dharmas, but the five aggregates such as form fully include conditioned dharmas, so this is said in particular.
As for the term â€œconditioned,â€ it refers to that which is produced by the convergence of many conditions. Since future [dharmas] have not yet arisen, how can they be called conditioned?
Because they belong to that category, they are also called conditioned.
It is like firewood that has not yet been burned, which is called firewood because it belongs to that category.
Or, the name is established based on what has been and what will be, without error, like a qin or se being called â€œhaving sound,â€ or like breasts, lotus flowers, and ponds.
Dharmas that do not arise do not go beyond that category, so they are called conditioned.
These conditioned dharmas are called â€œworldly paths,â€ etc., by the World-Honored One in various sÅ«tras according to their meanings.
What are they?

It is said that conditioned dharmas are also called â€œworldly paths,â€ because the five aggregates such as form are subject to arising and ceasing, and flow through the paths of future, present, and past, and because dharmas that do not arise are brought about by many conditions.
Even though they do not arise, because they belong to that category, it is not wrong to establish the name.
Some say:
Because it is swallowed by impermanence, it is called the path of the world, or it is called the basis of speech.
Speech refers to the sounds of speech, or it refers to the ability to speak, which is the distinction of the continuity of sound.
The basis refers to the meaning associated with names, which includes the five aggregates.
As a scripture says:
There are three bases of speech, not four or five.
This is why the Abhidharma-vibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra is well explained. It says that the basis of speech is included in the five aggregates.

Because that meaning has no logical basis for being associated with names.
As it is said, the basis of speech refers to the meaning associated with names.
If the meaning can be said to be associated with names, it is established as the basis of speech.

Because the meaning of the unconditioned has no logical basis for being associated with conditioned names, it is not established as the basis of speech, because there is no logical basis for it to fall into the world or transcend the world.
Or, because this cessation is established as the unconditioned, a scripture says:
The cessation of the aggregates is called cessation.
The cessation of the aggregates is not a basis for speech, because speech is a part of the aggregates.
There is another interpretation:

There is an interpretation that
it is also a basis for speech.

Or it is called â€œhaving separation,â€ because it is the eternal abandonment of the various destinies and the drowning in birth and death that is called â€œseparation.â€ It means the cessation of the eternal transmigration of the various destinies.

because a thing is a support or a basis, which means a cause.
Because the effect relies on the cause, arising from the cause, like a child relying on its mother.
Or because the effect abides in the cause, covering the cause, like a person abiding on a bed.
This is because the cause is obscured by the effect, due to the temporal sequence of cause and effect, and due to the difference in subtlety and coarseness.
This has a function, therefore it is called having a function, as explained above.
This only refers to the conditioned, and such categories are the different names for conditioned dharmas.
Among these conditioned dharmas that have been explained, the verse says:
Contaminated ones are called the aggregates of grasping, they are also called that which has conflict,
And suffering, origination, the world, the seen, the three existences, and so forth.
The treatise says:
Wasn't it said before that conditioned dharmas other than the noble truth of the path are called contaminated?
Why is it said again here?
Although it was said before, it is said again in order to show their different names and concepts, or to show the definition of those names and concepts.

The former passage says that all conditioned dharmas are called aggregates. The present passage says that only the impure are called grasped aggregates. The meaning of the former passage is that the pure are only called aggregates.

The name and concept of grasping is established among the impure dharmas, because they are able to grasp and produce the three realms of existence, or because they are able to hold and attract karma that leads to subsequent existence. Therefore they are called grasped.

The meaning here is that the aggregates and conflict are not born separately from each other.
The word and in the verse indicates other names for the impure.
That is, they are called suffering, which is the five grasped aggregates, because they are the basis of all oppression and because their own nature is coarse, heavy, and unstable.
Or it is called the origin, because it is the cause of that class of dharmas and because it causes them to be aggregated.
Or it is called the world, because it can be destroyed.
As the World Honored One said:
Because its nature can be destroyed, it is called the world.
If that is so, then the truth of the path should be the world.
No, because the second destruction does not exist. The nature of the destruction of the truth of the path is indefinite, while the nature of the destruction of the world is definite.

The primary elements will be discussed next.
Now we should briefly explain the characteristics of smoothness, roughness, etc.

This is a synonym for power, coarseness, solidity, and hardness, and can be used to suppress, so it is called heavy, which means being able to accomplish and subdue others.

The meaning of easily knowing their benefits and harms is that the desire for food is called hunger, and the desire for drink is called thirst.

Why are smoothness, etc. distinguished from each other?

Smoothness arises from the increase of the water and fire elements, roughness arises from the increase of the earth and wind elements, heaviness arises from the increase of the earth and water elements, and lightness arises from the increase of the fire and wind elements.

If so, why is it said that it is not separate from smoothness?
There is no fault in the existence or non-existence of each increase.
Or, suffocation is a distinction of smoothness, not just the nature of smoothness.
One should know that this cause also has distinctions.

Therefore, the nature of smoothness arises either from the increase of the water and wind elements, or from the increase of the water and fire elements. The reason for the two statements is not contradictory.
